news.summary: Although recent stock market volatility has pushed down prices for many stocks, the artificial intelligence (AI) sector remains a compelling investment, with the tremendous transformative potential it brings to many industries.  A newcomer to the AI space is the recent initial public offering (IPO) CoreWeave (NASDAQ: CRWV).  The company went public on March 28, and AI semiconductor powerhouse Nvidia was among those that bought shares.

Advanced Micro Devices (NasdaqGS:AMD) recently unveiled its 5th Gen AMD EPYC™ processors, significantly boosting Oracle Cloud Infrastructure's performance, as well as expanding its x86 embedded processor portfolio. Despite these announcements, the company's share price decreased by 15% over the past month. This decline occurs amid a broader tech sector downturn, with the Nasdaq entering bear market territory following heightened volatility due to a trade war with China. The tech-heavy index...

Articul8 has introduced A8-SupplyChain, a groundbreaking domain-specific Generative AI model designed to optimize supply chain, manufacturing, and industrial process operations. Leveraging autonomous reasoning and real-time decision-making capabilities, A8-SupplyChain surpasses the limitations of general-purpose language models by effectively handling complex industrial systems and translating technical documentation into actionable procedures. To say that the stock market has been volatile lately doesn't do the situation justice.  The S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) and several other major market indexes recently fell by more than 10% over a two-day period in response to President Trump's surprisingly high tariff rates.  The S&P 500 is now 18% below its February high, and with a 23% drop, the Nasdaq Composite (NASDAQINDEX: ^IXIC) is now firmly in bear market territory.
AMD stock catches a downgrade as Trump tariff fears spread throughout markets.

Nvidia has been an incredible growth stock, and it's been a bit of an anomaly -- no other stock within the index has come close to generating the same types of returns over the past decade.  Below, I'll look at who is in the second spot, and how close its returns are to Nvidia's.  The second-best-performing stock on the S&P 500 over the past decade is none other than Nvidia's rival Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ: AMD), more commonly referred to as AMD.
Nvidia has emerged as one of the most valuable companies in the world thanks to the AI movement, but the company's long-term growth looks questionable.

LPL Financial Holdings Inc. has appointed Vaughn Harvey as the executive vice president and chief data and artificial intelligence (AI) officer, marking a significant move in its AI strategy. With over 25 years of experience in AI-driven digital transformations, Harvey will spearhead LPL’s data and AI initiatives, enhancing digital transformation across the organization. (Bloomberg) -- Short sellers, or traders who wager on share price declines, are up $159 billion in paper profits over just six trading days after an escalating trade war sent the US stock market plummeting down more than 10%. The biggest market drawdown since 2022 on President Donald Trump’s pronouncement of sweeping worldwide tariffs made bets against an exchange traded fund tracking the S&P 500 Index, known as SPY, the most profitable short bet in that timeframe, according to data from S3 Part

Wall Street is overwhelmingly bullish on the stocks in this article, with price targets suggesting significant upside potential. However, it’s worth remembering that analysts rarely issue sell ratings, partly because their firms often seek other business from the same companies they cover.

Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is knocking on Nvidia’s (NVDA) door. Last week, the plucky semiconductor challenger announced the completion of its $4.9 billion acquisition of ZT Systems for its expertise in systems and rack-level design. The goal is to accelerate the design and deployment of AMD-powered AI infrastructure. This market is currently dominated by NVIDIA and is expected to exceed $1 trillion within a few years. AMD has introduced the 5th Gen AMD EPYC processors, which are now powering Google Cloud's new C4D and H4D virtual machines (VMs). These VMs offer significant enhancements in performance, scalability, and efficiency, specifically tailored for demanding cloud workloads including AI and high-performance computing (HPC).
